info.author: pepoluan
classifiers: License :: OSI Approved :: Mozilla Public License 2.0 (MPL 2.0)
Topic :: Software Development :: Libraries :: Python Modules
info.description:
=============
 multiworker
=============

Background
==========

Today's computers are almost always multicore machines. However, due to CPython's GIL, exploiting these multiple cores
are not simple. The ``multithreading`` module, for instance, are practically rendered impotent as multithreading won't
happen unless a thread is being tied up in an I/O operation.

However, Python provides a way to actually harness multicore parallelism: The ``multiprocessing`` module.

The problem with ``multiprocessing`` is that you are given a very 'low-level' plumbing mechanism. It provides you with
tools to create multiple (sub-)processes, tools to communicate between the (sub-)processes, tools to synchronize
between the (sub-)processes... but that's about it. When you start making programs to harness ``multiprocessing``'s
powers, you'll quickly find out that you have to keep building the exact same code structure. And along the way, you
keep 're-creating the wheel', so to speak.

This package aims to provide Python programmers with a 'slightly higher level' view of ``multiprocessing``, by removing
the necessity of keep having to create the 'harness' code.

*In a nutshell*, this code aims to be to ``multiprocessing`` what ``requests`` did for ``urllib``: Abstracting all the
plumbing and providing a more intuitive toolset to implement multicore-aware programs.
info.name: multiworker
